section.title: Math 140 Problems
section.p: Students entering Math 140 should be able to successfuly complete the problems below.

statement.p: Find the area of the triangle formed by the lines y=0, y=2x, and y=6-x.

solution.p: By graphing the indicated lines, we find the triangle shown below.
The intersection point can also be found algebraically by solving 2x=6-x to find that x=2. Plugging this in to either line gives y=4.
This triangle has width 6 and height 4, so its area is A=\frac{1}{2}(4)(6)=12.

statement.p: Compute the slopes of the lines L_1 and L_2 that are shown below.

solution.p: The line L_1 goes up 3 units as it moves to the right 1 unit (for example from (0,1) to (1,4)), so the slope of L_1 is 3.
The line L_2 goes down 1 unit as it moves to the right 2 units (for example from (0,5) to (2,4)), so the slope of L_2 is -\frac{1}{2}.

statement.p: If f(x)=16x-x^2, what is the area of the rectangle A?

solution.p: The area is length times height, so f(4)\cdot 4 = (16(4)-4^2)\cdot 4 = (64-16)\cdot 4 = 192

statement.p:
At what x-coordinates do the the graphs of the functions below intersect?
f(x) \amp = x^2-4x+3 g(x) \amp = -x^2+2x+3

solution.p:
Set the formulas equal to each other and solve for x:
x^2-4x+3 = x^2+2x+3
2x^2-6x=0
2x(x-3)=0
2x=0 \text{ or } x-3=0
x=0 \text{ or } x=3

statement.p: Suppose r(t) is a quadratic function. Describe how the graph of y=-r(t+4) is different from the graph of y=r(t).

solution.p: For the function r(t), the transformation -r(t+4) results in the graph being shifted 4 units to the left and reflected across the x-axis.

statement.p: Let h(x)=e^{3x+7}. Find functions f and g so that h(x)=f(g(x)).

solution.p: Set f(x)=e^x and g(x)=3x+7.

statement.p: Let C=f(A) be the cost in dollars of purchasing a plot of land of area A square feet. What do the quantities f(5000) and f^{-1}(250,000) represent?

solution.p: The quantity f(5000) is the cost (in dollars) of purchasing a plot of land of area 5000 square feet.
The quantity f^{-1}(250,000) is the area (in square feet) of a plot of land that you can purchase for 250,000 dollars.

statement.p:
Let f(x)=\dfrac{x^3-9x}{2x^3-6x^2}.
Identify the locations of the discontinuities of f(x) and classify them as holes or the location of a vertical asymptote.
Analyze the end behavior of f. That is, what happens as x goes towards \infty or -\infty?

li.p: First factor the denominator of f(x): 2x^3-6x^2=2x^2(x-3). The denominator equals 0 when x=0 or x=3, so those are the locations of the discontinuities.

To classify them, we factor the numerator as well and cancel where possible: x^3-9x=x(x^2-9)=x(x-3)(x+3). So \frac{x(x-3)(x+3)}{2x^2(x-3)}=\frac{x+3}{2x}. Since x-3 is no longer in the denominator after canceling, x=3 is a hole in the graph. Since x is still in the denominator, x=0 is a vertical asymptote of the graph.

ol.li: In the long run, f behaves like y=\dfrac{x^3}{2x^3}=\dfrac{1}{2}. That is, the graph has a horizontal asymptote of y=\frac{1}{2} to both the left and right.

statement.p: The enrollment at JU is given by the following graph of a linear function, where S represents the number of students and t represents the number of years since the year 2000.

ol.li: Using the two given points on the graph, determine the rate of change (slope) of the linear function.
How many students were there in the year 2000?
Determine a formula for S as a function of t.

The slope is found by computing rise over run using the given points:
\text{slope} = \frac{2744-2636}{4-1} = \frac{108}{3} = 36 .
The year 2000 corresponds to t=0, so we want the S-intercept of the line, which is 2600 students.
We know the slope and intercept of the line, so we use slope-intercept form: S(t) = 36t + 2600.

statement.p: The graph of y=f(x) is drawn below.

ol.li: Compute f(0).
What is the domain of f(x)?
What is the range of f(x)?
The domain is all valid x-values on the graph, so the domain of f(x) is the set of values -4 \leq x \leq 2, which can be written as [-4,2] using interval notation.

The range is all valid y-values on the graph (or all possible outputs of the function), so the range of f(x) is the set of values -1.5 \leq y \leq 2, which can be written as [-1.5, 2] using interval notation.

statement.p: For which values of b is y(x)=5e^{bx} an increasing function? For which values of b is it a decreasing function?

solution.p: The function is increasing when b\gt 0 and is decreasing when b \lt 0.

statement.p: Suppose the population of a certain small country is given by P(t)=19.5e^{0.01t}, where P is the population in millions, t years after the year 2000. Calculate and describe the meaning of P(8). Include units in your answer.

solution.p:
P(8)=19.5e^{0.01(8)}\approx 43.398 \text{ million people}
This means that in the year 2008, the population of the small country was approximately 43.398 million people (43,398,000 people).

statement.p: For a 180 pound man, blood alcohol content (BAC) decreases linearly by 0.015 every hour if he does not consume any more alcohol. If at the start of the hour, he has a BAC of 0.13, how many minutes must he wait before his BAC falls below the legal driving limit of 0.08?

solution.p:
If B is the the blood alcohol content (BAC) of the man, and t is the number of hours after the man has stopped consuming alcohol, then B can be modeled by B(t)=-0.015t + 0.13. To answer the question, we solve B(t)=0.08 for t:
-0.015t + 0.13 = 0.08 -0.015t = 0.08-0.13 -0.015t = -0.05 t = \frac{-0.05}{-0.015}=\frac{10}{3} \text{ hours} . So he must wait 3 hours and 20 minutes for his BAC to reach 0.08.

statement.p:

The population is at its minimum number of rabbits at the beginning of January and increases in size to its maximum at the beginning of July. The population P of rabbits (in thousands) t months after January 1 is given by P(t)=-5\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{6}t\right) + 10.
What is the maximum population of rabbits each year? What is the minimum population of rabbits each year?

solution.p: The fourth graph is the graph of y=\sin(x), and the second graph is the graph of y=\cos(x).

statement.p: If 0 \leq \theta \leq \pi/2 and \sin(\theta)=\dfrac{4}{7}, what are the exact values of \cos(\theta) and \tan(\theta)?

solution.p: Using \sin(\theta)=\dfrac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}}, we create a right triangle with one leg length 4 and the hypotenuse length 7. Then the leg adjacent to angle \theta has length \sqrt{7^2-4^2}=\sqrt{49-16}=\sqrt{33}.

Using \cos(\theta)=\dfrac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}} and \tan(\theta)=\dfrac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}}, we obtain \cos(\theta)=\dfrac{\sqrt{33}}{7} and \tan(\theta)=\dfrac{4}{\sqrt{33}}.

statement.p: Fully simplify the expression \dfrac{\sin^2(x)}{\tan^2(x)} + \tan^2(x)\cos^2(x).

solution.p:
Since \tan(x)=\dfrac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}, we have
\frac{\sin^2(x)}{\tan^2(x)} \amp = \sin^2(x) \cdot \frac{1}{\tan^2(x)} \amp = \sin^2(x) \cdot \frac{\cos^2(x)}{\sin^2(x)} \amp = \cos^2(x)
and
\tan^2(x) \cos^2(x) \amp = \frac{\sin^2(x)}{\cos^2(x)}\cos^2(x) \amp = \sin^2(x) . So \frac{\sin^2(x)}{\tan^2(x)} + \tan^2(x)\cos^2(x) = \cos^2(x) +\sin^2(x) =1.

statement.p: Find an equation for the line passing through the points (-2,5) and (4,-3).

solution.p: We first find the slope of the line, which is m=\frac{-3-5}{4-(-2)}= \frac{-8}{6}=-\frac{4}{3}. Using point-slope form with the point (-2,5) and the slope m=-\dfrac{4}{3}, the line has equation y-5=-\frac{4}{3}(x+2).
Additional correct answers include y+3=-\frac{4}{3}(x-4) and y=-\frac{4}{3}x+\frac{7}{3}.
